The patient presents with a classic Brown-Séquard syndrome (hemicord syndrome). There is ipsilateral (right-sided) Upper Motor Neuron weakness (spasticity, hyperreflexia, extensor plantar) and ipsilateral loss of dorsal column sensations (proprioception, vibration). Contralaterally (left side), there is loss of spinothalamic modalities (pain/pinprick). The 'band of numbness across the stomach' on the right suggests radicular involvement at the level of the lesion, localising it to the thoracic segments (likely T6-T10).
